articles.headline: Israel Resumes Offensive in Gaza Strip After Truce With Hamas Ends
articles.snippet: Talks on extending a weeklong cease-fire broke down, with each side blaming the other. The truce had included the release of hostages held in Gaza for people in Israeli prisons.
articles.abstract: Talks on extending a weeklong cease-fire broke down, with each side blaming the other. The truce had included the release of hostages held in Gaza for people in Israeli prisons.
articles.lead_paragraph: A weeklong cease-fire in the Gaza Strip collapsed on Friday morning, with Israel and Hamas blaming each other for the breakdown of a truce that had allowed for the exchange of hundreds of hostages and prisoners, and that had briefly raised hopes for a more lasting halt to the fighting.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Ben Hubbard and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Sandra O’Connor’s Extraordinary Final Chapter
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court justice found herself balancing conflicting demands of professional achievement and family expectations to the end.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court justice found herself balancing conflicting demands of professional achievement and family expectations to the end.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sandra Day O’Connor gave up lifetime tenure on the Supreme Court — a job she loved and one with extraordinary power — to care for her husband of 52 years as he deteriorated from dementia.

articles.headline: Netflix Builds a ‘Squid Game’ Universe as It Awaits a Second Season
articles.snippet: A reality show and a live experience are two ways of keeping the dystopian series in the public eye. Is the original’s bleak message being diluted?
articles.abstract: A reality show and a live experience are two ways of keeping the dystopian series in the public eye. Is the original’s bleak message being diluted?
articles.lead_paragraph: On the same soundstage where Bob Barker lorded over “The Price Is Right,” “Squid Game” is coming to life.

articles.headline: Drunk and Asleep on the Job: Air Traffic Controllers Pushed to the Brink
articles.snippet: A nationwide shortage of controllers has resulted in an exhausted and demoralized work force that is increasingly prone to making dangerous mistakes.
articles.abstract: A nationwide shortage of controllers has resulted in an exhausted and demoralized work force that is increasingly prone to making dangerous mistakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: One air traffic controller went into work drunk this summer and joked about “making big money buzzed.” Another routinely smoked marijuana during breaks. A third employee threatened violence and then “aggressively pushed” a colleague who was directing airplanes.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Israel Orders Evacuations Amid ‘Intense’ Attacks on Southern Gaza
articles.snippet: Beleaguered Gazans, having fled the territory’s north, emerged from a night of bombardment wondering where to go next for safety.
articles.abstract: Beleaguered Gazans, having fled the territory’s north, emerged from a night of bombardment wondering where to go next for safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Israeli military heavily bombarded southern Gaza on Saturday and ordered residents of several Palestinian border towns in the area to leave their homes, appearing to set the stage for a ground invasion in the south as hostilities resumed after the collapse of a weeklong truce with Hamas.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Rawan Sheikh Ahmad and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Ego, Fear and Money: How the A.I. Fuse Was Lit
articles.snippet: The people who were most afraid of the risks of artificial intelligence decided they should be the ones to build it. Then distrust fueled a spiraling competition.
articles.abstract: The people who were most afraid of the risks of artificial intelligence decided they should be the ones to build it. Then distrust fueled a spiraling competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk celebrated his 44th birthday in July 2015 at a three-day party thrown by his wife at a California wine country resort dotted with cabins. It was family and friends only, with children racing around the upscale property in Napa Valley.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz, Karen Weise, Nico Grant and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: ‘Medical Freedom’ Activists Take Aim at New Target: Childhood Vaccine Mandates
articles.snippet: Mississippi has long had high childhood immunization rates, but a federal judge has ordered the state to allow parents to opt out on religious grounds.
articles.abstract: Mississippi has long had high childhood immunization rates, but a federal judge has ordered the state to allow parents to opt out on religious grounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than 40 years, Mississippi had one of the strictest school vaccination requirements in the nation, and its high childhood immunization rates have been a source of pride. But in July, the state began excusing children from vaccination if their parents cited religious objections, after a federal judge sided with a “medical freedom” group.

articles.headline: Why More Chinese Are Risking Danger in Southern Border Crossings to U.S.
articles.snippet: Trekking the perilous Darién Gap and seeking asylum are risks worth taking for migrants from China who have lost hope in the country’s future.
articles.abstract: Trekking the perilous Darién Gap and seeking asylum are risks worth taking for migrants from China who have lost hope in the country’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gao Zhibin and his daughter left Beijing on Feb. 24 for a better life, a safer one. Over the next 35 days, by airplane, train, boat, bus and foot, they traveled through nine countries. By the time they touched American soil in late March, Mr. Gao had lost 30 pounds.

articles.headline: Why Doctors and Pharmacists Are in Revolt
articles.snippet: Once accustomed to a status outside the usual management-labor hierarchy, many health professionals now feel as put upon as any clock-punching worker.
articles.abstract: Once accustomed to a status outside the usual management-labor hierarchy, many health professionals now feel as put upon as any clock-punching worker.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. John Wust does not come off as a labor agitator. A longtime obstetrician-gynecologist from Louisiana with a penchant for bow ties, Dr. Wust spent the first 15 years of his career as a partner in a small business — that is, running his own practice with colleagues.

articles.headline: Team’s Sale Reflects Growing Links Between Pro Sports and Gambling
articles.snippet: The proposed purchase of the N.B.A.’s Dallas Mavericks by a casino operator is the latest sign of how fully leagues have embraced the gaming world.
articles.abstract: The proposed purchase of the N.B.A.’s Dallas Mavericks by a casino operator is the latest sign of how fully leagues have embraced the gaming world.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, professional sports organizations like the National Basketball Association and Major League Baseball prohibited liquor companies from buying advertising in locations in stadiums and arenas that could be seen on television, in deference to efforts to curb drunken driving.

articles.headline: Alaska Airlines Plans to Buy Hawaiian Airlines
articles.snippet: The deal, valued at $1.9 billion, would further consolidate the airline industry and is likely to face close scrutiny by federal antitrust regulators.
articles.abstract: The deal, valued at $1.9 billion, would further consolidate the airline industry and is likely to face close scrutiny by federal antitrust regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alaska Airlines said on Sunday that it planned to buy Hawaiian Airlines for $1.9 billion, a deal that would further consolidate the airline industry and probably attract the scrutiny of federal regulators.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi and Ivan Penn

articles.headline: Israel, Expanding Offensive, Tells More Gazans to Evacuate
articles.snippet: As its ground forces prepared to move in the south of Gaza, residents there were told to leave their homes, spreading fear and confusion.
articles.abstract: As its ground forces prepared to move in the south of Gaza, residents there were told to leave their homes, spreading fear and confusion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid a barrage of airstrikes, Israel sharply expanded its evacuation orders in the Gaza Strip on Sunday in preparation for an expected ground invasion in the southern part of the territory.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee, Iyad Abuheweila and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: China Evergrande Gets an Unexpected Reprieve From Liquidation
articles.snippet: A Hong Kong judge postponed deciding whether to force the breakup of the property developer, which defaulted in 2021 on hundreds of billions of dollars in debt.
articles.abstract: A Hong Kong judge postponed deciding whether to force the breakup of the property developer, which defaulted in 2021 on hundreds of billions of dollars in debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once China’s most prolific property developer, China Evergrande has narrowly averted a long-expected liquidation.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Tiffany May

articles.headline: It Could Be a Vast Source of Clean Energy, Buried Deep Underground
articles.snippet: In eastern France, and in other places around the world, deposits of natural hydrogen promise bountiful power. But questions remain.
articles.abstract: In eastern France, and in other places around the world, deposits of natural hydrogen promise bountiful power. But questions remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the rocky soil of Lorraine, a former coal mining region near the French-German border, scientists guided a small probe one recent day down a borehole half a mile into the earth’s crust.

articles.headline: After Decades of Decline, a Feathered Icon Breeds in New Zealand’s Capital
articles.snippet: The national bird, the kiwi, has hatched eggs in the wild in the Wellington area for the first time in living memory, thanks to a multiyear conservation effort.
articles.abstract: The national bird, the kiwi, has hatched eggs in the wild in the Wellington area for the first time in living memory, thanks to a multiyear conservation effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the foot of a towering fern, Pete Kirkman pushed his hand through a curtain of dead branches into a burrow. His fingers settled on a lump of feathers. Gently, he withdrew a fist-sized hatchling.

articles.headline: A Prison at War: The Convicts Sustaining Putin’s Invasion
articles.snippet: Nearly 200 inmates left a high-security Russian prison to join the war in Ukraine, seeking redemption, money or freedom. Many were killed or wounded.
articles.abstract: Nearly 200 inmates left a high-security Russian prison to join the war in Ukraine, seeking redemption, money or freedom. Many were killed or wounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: Aleksandr Mokin had lost the will to live.
articles.byline: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Ekaterina Bodyagina, Alina Lobzina, Oleg Matsnev and Gray Beltran

articles.headline: Why a Second Trump Presidency May Be More Radical Than His First
articles.snippet: Donald Trump has long exhibited authoritarian impulses, but his policy operation is now more sophisticated, and the buffers to check him are weaker.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump has long exhibited authoritarian impulses, but his policy operation is now more sophisticated, and the buffers to check him are weaker.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1989, the Chinese Communist Party used tanks and troops to crush a pro-democracy protest in Beijing’s Tiananmen Square. Most of the West, across traditional partisan lines, was aghast at the crackdown that killed at least hundreds of student activists. But one prominent American was impressed.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: White House Warns Ukraine Aid Is Running Out, Pressing Congress for More
articles.snippet: The warning, in a letter to congressional leaders, comes as Republican support for funding Kyiv’s war effort is waning, and an emergency funding package is stalled in Congress.
articles.abstract: The warning, in a letter to congressional leaders, comes as Republican support for funding Kyiv’s war effort is waning, and an emergency funding package is stalled in Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: The White House warned congressional leaders on Monday that the United States would run out of money to send weapons to Ukraine by year’s end, severely jeopardizing Kyiv’s ability to defend itself against Russia if lawmakers fail to approve emergency military aid soon.
articles.byline: By Karoun Demirjian and Lara Jakes
